desc: This course focuses on three great decolonization movements-Communism, Nationalism, and Islamism-in the postcolonial Islamic world, in an attempt to understand the impact of the 9/11/2001 terrorists attacks on the social, political, and cultural life of Muslims in predominantly Islamic countries and diasporic communities in the West. Honors version available

name: Monuments and Memory
desc: Explores the role of monuments in the formation of cultural memory and identity, both nationally and globally. Topics include the construction of identities in and through public spaces, commemoration of both singular individuals and ordinary citizens, and the appearance of new types of post-traumatic monuments in the 20th century.

name: Historical Time
desc: This course explores the ways in which Western historians and other students of the past from Adam Ferguson to Stephen Jay Gould have conceptualized and packaged historical time. Honors version available

name: Gender, Military, and War in Comparative Perspective
desc: This course introduces students to new research on the history of gender, the military, and war in a comparative perspective. It explores the interrelations between changing military systems, types of warfare, the gender order, as well as political, social, and cultural currents in modern history.

name: Colloquium in World Military History
desc: Reading colloquium in world military history, emphasizing Europe, focusing on the most significant issues, methods, and approaches in the field today.

name: History of the Andes
desc: This course offers a survey of the history of the Andean region. The primary focus will be either the pre-Inca, Inca, and colonial periods or the 19th and 20th centuries, depending on the instructor.

name: Mexico, 1750-1870: War, Independence, and Reforms: Citizenship and Conflict in a New Nation
desc: This upper-division course focuses on the major issues, debates, and conflicts that arose over citizenship in a multi-ethnic society, tensions between church and state, and the definition of national territory in Mexico as a new and modernizing nation.

name: History of the Caribbean
desc: Thematic approach to the history of the West Indies, with emphasis on the period from European conquest through the 20th century. Topics include colonialism, slavery, monoculture, United States-Caribbean relations, and decolonization.

name: History of Cuba
desc: Thematic approach to Cuban history, from conquest to the revolution. Attention is given to socioeconomic developments, slavery and race relations, the 19th-century independence process, and the 20th-century republic.

name: History of Brazil
desc: This course is concerned primarily with the creation of a new society through race mixture and culture change, and with the political and economic development of Brazil.

name: The African Diaspora
desc: A comparative examination of the movements, experiences, and contributions of Africans and people of African descent from the period of the Atlantic slave trade to the present.

name: Women and Gender in African History
desc: Analysis of historical transformations in Africa and their effects on women's lives and gender relations. Particular themes include precolonial societies, colonialism, religious change, urban labor, nationalism, and sexuality. Honors version available

name: Revolution in the Modern Middle East
desc: This course will focus on revolutionary change in the Middle East during the last century, emphasizing internal social, economic, and political conditions as well as international contexts.

name: Women in the Middle East
desc: Explores the lives of women in the Middle East and how they have changed over time. Focus will change each year.

name: The Middle East and the West
desc: This course explores changing interactions between the Middle East and the West, including trade, warfare, scientific exchange, and imperialism, and ends with an analysis of contemporary relations in light of the legacy of the past.

name: The Economic History of Southeast Asia
desc: This course is intended as a broad overview of Southeast Asian economic history from premodern times to the present day.

name: Gender in Chinese History
desc: This course is designed to introduce undergraduates to recent historical scholarship in the field of Chinese gender studies. Topics include family and kinship, the body and bodily practices, social space, writing, sexuality, work, and law, covering both the premodern and modern periods. No prior coursework required.

name: Bandits, Rebels and Storytellers:  Fiction and History in India
desc: This course examines the histories, representations, and cultural perceptions surrounding bandits and rebels in modern India. The representations of bandits and rebels are studied in the light of the emergence of nationalism, shifting notions of gender and masculinity, race relations, and emergence of capitalist structures.

name: Oral History and Performance
desc: This course combines readings and field work in oral history with the study of performance as a means of interpreting and conveying oral history texts. Honors version available
Grading: Letter gradeSame as: COMM 562, FOLK 562, WGST 562.

name: Civil War and Reconstruction, 1848-1900
desc: Focus is on causes, nature, and consequences of the Civil War.

name: The History of Sexuality in America
desc: A history of the sexual practices, desires, and understandings of Americans, from earliest colonial encounters to the late 20th century.

name: Women in the South
desc: An exploration of the distinctive themes in Southern women's lives, using the evidence of history and literature.

name: The Vietnam War
desc: A wide-ranging exploration of America's longest war, from 19th-century origins to 1990s legacies, from village battlegrounds to the Cold War context, from national leadership to popular participation and impact.

name: Southern Music
desc: Explores the history of music in the American South from its roots to 20th-century musical forms, revealing how music serves as a window on the region's history and culture.

name: The Ethnohistory of Native American Women
desc: Introduces students to the study of Native American women through the perspectives of anthropology, history, and autobiography.

name: United States Foreign Relations in the 20th Century
desc: How the United States came to occupy a leading role in world affairs as a diplomatic, military, economic, and cultural power and what that role has meant to Americans and to other peoples, especially during the Cold War.

name: Transatlantic Relations and Contemporary Geo-Politics from the Cold War to the Present
desc: This course considers transatlantic relations in its security, political, and economic dimensions. The course also analyzes U.S. attempts to construct a more united European continent. It is the main aim of this course to give students a structured overview of transatlantic relations and geo-political developments from 1945 to the present.

name: American Constitutional History to 1876
desc: In a classroom environment characterized by discussion, simulation, and interaction, the antecedents, formation, and interpretation of the Constitution are confronted in a broad historical matrix.

name: American Constitutional History since 1876
desc: Using a classroom environment similar to HIST 581, constitutional adjustments and change are related to psychological, political, social, and economic factors, and to Supreme Court members.

name: The Promise of Urbanization: American Cities in the 19th and 20th Centuries
desc: A survey of the development of American cities since 1815 and their influence upon American history.

name: Race, Basketball, and the American Dream
desc: This course explores how Americans have used basketball for integration, economic mobility, and political protest. Particular focus is on how black Americans have used the game for individual expression and political and economic advancement; and the ways the game has influenced ideas about race, whiteness
Repeat: HS, US.

name: The New South
desc: This course explores the transformation of the South from the time of the Civil War and emancipation to the contemporary rise of the Sunbelt.

name: Race, Racism, and America: (United States) Law in Historical Perspective
desc: This course will historically and critically examine the changing legal status of people of color in the United States. Within a broad historical matrix from the colonial era to the present, it will focus on African Americans, Native Americans, Asian Americans, Latina/os, and United States law.

name: Exploring the U
desc: Interning at the SOHP offers experiential education in the intellectual, organizational, and practical work of oral history. You will learn to do oral history interviews, contribute to a collaborative research project, and help this esteemed research center with programming, processing interviews, communications, and digital projects. We accept four interns per semester and you must apply through the Southern Oral History Program.

name: Technology and American Culture
desc: Technology's impact on American thought and society and the response it has engendered. Topics will include the factory town, search for utopia, impact of Henry Ford, war, and depersonalization.

name: Introduction to Oral History
desc: Introduces students to the uses of interviews in historical research. Questions of ethics, interpretation, and the construction of memory will be explored, and interviewing skills will be developed through field work.

name: Introduction to Public History
desc: Introduces the theory, politics, and practice of historical work conducted in public venues (museums, historic sites, national parks, government agencies, archives), directed at public audiences, or addressed to public issues.

name: Writing for a Popular Audience
desc: A seminar on the art of translating academic expertise for a general audience. Students read model works ranging from philosophy to biology, workshop story ideas, and learn how to publish in print and online media. Open to all disciplines.

name: Honors in History
desc: Permission of the instructor. Introduction to the methods of historical research; designed to lead to the completion of an honors essay.

name: Honors in History
desc: Permission of the instructor. Introduction to the methods of historical research; designed to lead to the completion of an honors essay.

name: Thinking Historically
desc: Introduces students to the intellectual currents and schools of thought that have characterized the historical profession over time. By examining such diverse conceptual frameworks, students will prepare themselves to tackle more confidently the research projects they will design and execute in HIST 900 and 901.

name: Introduction to Medieval and Early Modern Studies
desc: This is an interdisciplinary course to introduce graduate students to the sources, methods, and approaches of medieval studies.

name: Introduction to Historical Education
desc: Provides an introduction to teaching history. Topics include the history of historical education, planning a course, the role of the teacher, goals and methods, using new technologies, and evaluating students.

name: Professional Lives of Historians
desc: In this course, students explore the many identities of professional historians. Through readings and assignments, students learn about the state and future of the historical profession, develop skills that will serve them in their careers, and identify their own goals as professional historians and/or public intellectuals.

name: Introductory Colloquium on Early Modern Europe
desc: Directed readings on early European history, from Britain through European Russia.

name: Introductory Colloquium on Modern Europe
desc: Directed readings on modern European history, from Britain through European Russia.

name: Introductory Colloquium in Latin American History before 1810
desc: Directed readings on Latin American history from preconquest to 1810; required for students entering the field.

name: Introductory Colloquium in the History of Latin America since 1810
desc: Directed readings on Latin American history in the National Period; required for students entering the field.

name: Introduction to Military History
desc: An introduction to the methods, issues, and literature of military history, including classic works and scholarship representative of a variety of approaches from history and other disciplines.

name: Readings in African History
desc: An introduction to major works and themes in the history of premodern and modern African history.

name: Introduction to Asian History
desc: An introduction to major works and themes in the history of Asia with an emphasis on the history of China, Japan, and South Asia.

name: Readings in European Expansion and Global Interaction, 1400-1800
desc: Examines the dynamics of cross-cultural contacts and exchange between Europe and other civilizations in the context of a growing global interconnectedness.

name: Readings in Contemporary Global History
desc: Focus on the 19th and 20th centuries. Mixing theory, case studies, and comparisons, the readings reflect disciplinary diversity.

name: Readings in Global Cold War History
desc: A historiographical overview of the Cold War in a global context, 1945-1991. The course familiarizes students with major works in the field and the latest scholarship.

name: Selected Readings in the Comparative or Global History of Women and Gender
desc: Readings in the history of women and gender in a comparative, global, or transnational perspective.

name: Introductory Colloquium in United States History to 1788
desc: Directed readings on American history from the precolonial period through the American Revolution; required for students entering the field.

name: Introductory Colloquium in United States History, 1788 to 1900
desc: Directed readings on American history from the Constitution through the end of the nineteenth century; required for students entering the field.

name: Introductory Colloquium in United States History since 1900
desc: Directed readings on American history in the twentieth century; required for students entering the field.

name: Feminist and Gender Theory for Historians
desc: Readings in contemporary feminist and gender theory, focused especially on theories that address the construction, writing, and general practice of history.

name: Readings in the History of Sexuality and Gender
desc: Readings on the historical study of gender and sexuality and on definitions of femininity and masculinity in different historical contexts.

name: Readings in the History of Science and Medicine
desc: Examines the principal historiographical problems in the history of science and medicine, focusing on a different topic each year.

name: History and Memory: An Introduction into Theory, Methodology, and Research
desc: This graduate seminar explores the theory, methodology, and scholarship on history and memory, and examines some broad questions about the importance of studying collective memory. We will seek to understand both, different theoretical and methodological approaches, and their practical use in historical research and writing.

name: The Holocaust, Genocide and Historical Methodology
desc: This seminar will familiarize students with foundational works of Holocaust historiography as well as with newer works that challenge old interpretations and methodologies. Throughout the course we will look at the mutual influences of historical writing and memory of the Holocaust as societies have come to terms with the dark past of the Second World War; the course will also examine historical writing itself as a form of representation and memory.

name: History and the Social Sciences
desc: The relationship of the social sciences to history, logic of inquiry, use of quantitative methods, and introduction to the computer.

name: Problems in Greek History, 600-323 BCE
desc: Permission of the instructor. This course introduces graduate students to problems in the use of literary, epigraphic, and archaeological sources for a range of issues, including religion, law, and warfare.

name: History of Rome, 27 BCE-180 CE
desc: Readings, reports, and discussions on selected topics of current importance for the field. Topics to be announced in advance.

name: Readings in Medieval and Early Modern Women's History
desc: A readings course on the history of women, gender, and sexuality in Medieval Europe.

name: Medieval England
desc: Prerequisite, HIST 437.

name: Late Medieval England
desc: Readings in English history, ca. 1300-1500, with a focus on social, economic, political, and legal topics.

name: Europe in the 16th Century
desc: A survey of the best historical literature emphasizing churches, varieties of secular power, and religious practice.

name: Readings in Early Modern European History
desc: Selected readings and discussion of topics and relevant historiography in early modern Europe.

name: Early Modern Germany
desc: A topical survey of the political, social, and economic history of early modern Germany.

name: Problems in the History of the French Revolution
desc: Readings, reports, and discussion on aspects of the French Revolutionary upheaval in Europe.

name: Readings in Modern European Women's and Gender History
desc: A readings course in the history of women in Europe since 1500.

name: Topics in Modern European History
desc: This course examines particular themes, events, and historiographical debates of Modern European History in a seminar setting.

name: Readings in the Intellectual History of Europe
desc: A readings course on specific themes and debates in modern European intellectual life.

name: Readings in European Social History
desc: This graduate readings course discusses classic works as well as recent landmark books about the development of European society in the 19th and 20th centuries.

name: Readings in Modern European History, 1918-1945
desc: Directed readings, varying from year to year, selected from historiographical classics as well as the most recent scholarly publications.

name: Studies in Modern English History
desc: Directed readings in 19th- and 20th-century English history. Topics vary from year to year.

name: Topics in French History
desc: Open to graduate students from all departments. This course examines one period or one set of problems within French history since the Renaissance. Topics determined by instructor.

name: Colonialism and European Visual Culture, 1800-1990
desc: Considers the role of visual representation in the construction of European empire and its associated knowledges from the Napoleonic expedition to Egypt to debates over primitivism in the 1980s.

name: Readings in Russian History, 1796-1917
desc: Selected readings and discussion of various topics in the history of Russia from the late 18th century to the Russian Revolution.

name: Readings in Soviet History
desc: A historiographical reading colloquium covering Soviet and post-Soviet Russian history, 1917-present. The course familiarizes students with Western, Soviet, and post-Soviet literature on the most important issues in Soviet history.

name: Introduction to Russian, Eurasian, and East European History
desc: This interdisciplinary seminar provides an in-depth look at some of the major topics in modern Russian, East European, and Eurasian history.

name: Readings in East European History
desc: Directed readings on modern East European history.

name: Readings in Modern Centeral Asian History
desc: The peoples of Islamic Central Eurasia are united by linguistic, cultural, and religious ties. Their history is divided between study fields: Soviet/Russian, Chinese, and Islamic Studies. Course takes historiographical diversity as a point of departure, interrogating the major debates that have animated the study of Islamic Central Asia across disciplines.

name: Colonial Encounters:
desc: This course introduces students to a variety of theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of colonialism. It encourages them to examine critically the ways in which scholars apply and use the concepts of coloniality" and "postcoloniality
Prereqs: and to assess the avenues through which those concepts might prove to be productive in informing their own research.

name: History of Muslim Societies in Asia and Africa
desc: This graduate course will examine the intellectual, political and cultural history of Muslim societies since 1492 through the methodology and approaches of global history.

name: Topics in African History
desc: A readings-based course on particular topics or approaches in African history. Topics may vary by semester and will be announced in advance.

name: Topics in Asian History
desc: Instructors use this course to focus on particular topics or historical approaches related to Asian history.

name: Problems in Latin American History
desc: Instructors use this course to focus on particular topics or approaches in Latin American history. Topics to be announced in advance.

name: Biography and Memoir in Modern Latin American History
desc: This graduate seminar examines the role of biography and memoir in national-period Latin American historiography.

name: Readings in Early American History
desc: Selected readings and research in United States history and its multicultural dimensions up to the American Revolution.

name: The United States in the Federal Period, 1789-1820
desc: Readings, discussion, and book lists designed to give familiarity with the historiographical problems, research opportunities, and bibliography of the period.

name: The United States in the Middle Period, 1815-1860
desc: An analysis of the material and ideological transformations within the antebellum republic, which climaxed in the sectional crisis of the 1850s.

name: Readings in the Antebellum South
desc: A review of traditional and modern literature on the pre-Civil War South, focusing on the interrelationships of its economy, society, culture, and politics.

name: Civil War and Reconstruction, 1860-1876
desc: An intensive readings course on key works comprising the core historiography for Civil War-Reconstruction America. Discussions, short papers, and a 20-page historiographical paper comprise the bulk of the assignments.

name: Readings in the South since Reconstruction
desc: Readings, reports, and discussions on selected topics with a view to gaining familiarity with the literature of the field.

name: Political and Social History of Modern America
desc: A course of readings for advanced students that relate social history to the history of the state in America in the period from the Great Depression and the New Deal to the present.

name: Readings in United States Labor History
desc: A graduate reading seminar on the history of America's workers from the 20th century to the present. The struggle of American workers to achieve a measure of dignity and security is examined from social, economic, and political perspectives. The course critically evaluates recent scholarship in the field of labor history.

name: Colloquium in United States Military History
desc: Reading colloquium in United States military history focusing on the most significant issues, methods, and approaches in the field today.

name: History of United States Foreign Relations
desc: Readings and research exploring various topics in modern American foreign relations and diplomacy.

name: Readings in Urban History
desc: A readings course to introduce students to the main topics in urban history.

name: 19th and 20th Century American Labor History
desc: Graduate reading seminar in American labor history intended for students doing research as well as those writing M.A. and doctoral theses. Graduate students from fields other than United States history welcome. Students will read texts and articles by scholars in a wide variety of fields of American labor history.

name: Readings in United States Women's and Gender History
desc: A readings course on the history of women and gender in the United States.

name: Readings in African American History
desc: Graduate students compile bibliographies and read important contributions to various aspects of African American history, stressing shifts in African American historiography and including very recent works.

name: Topics in American Cultural History
desc: Research seminar exploring various topics in United States cultural history to be announced in advance.

name: Readings in Native American History
desc: Readings in and discussions of the major works in Native American history.

name: Readings in the Global History of Capitalism
desc: This course exposes graduate students to the classical and burgeoning debates among historians over the history of global capitalism around the world from its antecedents in the medieval and early modern period until the present.

name: Topics in History for Graduates
desc: Instructors use this course to focus on particular topics or historical approaches. Specific course descriptions are available each semester on the departmental Web site (www.unc.edu/depts/history).

name: Independent Study for Graduate Students
desc: Permission of the instructor. Independent reading programs for graduate students whose needs are covered by no course immediately available. For students resident in Chapel Hill or vicinity.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Crafting a Historical Project
desc: Intended to help students develop a plan of research and writing, select a bibliography, develop an understanding of the literature available for their topic, and articulate a problem or facet of the topic to which they can contribute original research in their M.A. thesis.

name: M
desc: A seminar for those preparing the M.A. thesis. Pursuing original research in primary sources, students prepare full drafts of their theses.

name: Writing for Historians: A Seminar on the Craft of Historical Writing
desc: Doctoral students focus intensively on the writing process to produce an article-length piece of work suitable for publication. Topics include quotation, translation, narrative technique, structuring argument, and addressing a wide audience.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit.

name: Dissertation Design
desc: Required of all doctoral candidates in the last semester of course work, this practicum helps students refine a dissertation topic and produce a prospectus.

name: Dissertation Seminar
desc: A seminar for A.B.D. students, offered as demand and resources permit.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Ancient History
desc: Research seminar on selected topics of current importance for the field. Topics to be announced in advance.

name: Medieval Dissertation Design
desc: This course complements HIST 905, focusing on specific skills, sources, and methods for designing a dissertation prospectus in the field of medieval European history.

name: Historiography and Narrative: Ancient, Medieval and Early Modern
desc: This course involves the close study of narrative historiographical texts before 1700. It introduces students to narratological approaches to textual analysis as well as to scholarly work, in a variety of disciplines, on the question of memory. The course is interdisciplinary in its orientation.

name: Research Seminar in African History
desc: Intended to accommodate students at various stages in their graduate careers, this multipurpose seminar will focus on problems in modern African history.

name: Seminar in Modern European History
desc: This writing seminar explores the process of working with primary sources, creating a narrative, and shaping an interpretation based on examples from the last two centuries of European history.

name: Seminar in Russian and East European History
desc: A multi-purpose writing seminar on Russian and Soviet history in which students may write a seminar paper, M.A. thesis, dissertation prospectus, or dissertation chapter.

name: American Revolution, 1763-1789
desc: Research seminar exploring various topics related to United States history in the late 18th century around the time of the American Revolution.

name: Research in Native American History
desc: This course introduces graduate students to research methods in Native American history, including the methodology of ethnohistory and the techniques of compiling a source base, taking notes, and outlining.

name: Introductory Seminar in Military History
desc: Introduction to research that should result in a major research product. Students will alternate reading classic texts in military history with discussions of project conceptualization and research strategies.

name: Advanced Seminar in Military History
desc: A research seminar designed to bring major projects (usually an M.A. thesis) to completion.

name: Seminar in Latin American History
desc: All students will be required to complete an original research paper based on use of primary sources on a Latin American topic corresponding to the theme of the seminar to be announced in advance.

name: Seminar in Women's and Gender History
desc: Writing seminar for graduate students on all levels who work on the history of women and gender.

name: Seminar in History
desc: Given on demand and as resources permit, this seminar allows faculty to respond to student interest in particular topics.

name: Master's Research and Thesis
desc: Individual work on the M.A . thesis, pursued under the supervision of the M.A.  advisor.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit.

name: Doctoral Research and Dissertation
desc: Individual work on the doctoral dissertation, pursued under the supervision of the Ph.D. advisor.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.
